content: bottom to top each black square represents a stitch worked in your main colour whilst the white squares represent stitches worked in your contrast colour the grey squares represent stitches that you will form further along in the chart two-stranded colourwork in stranded colourwork you alternate between using your main colour and a contrast colour for this pattern i recommend that you hold your main colour in your dominant hand and to hold your contrast colour in your non-dominant hand or to hold both yarns in one hand but position your main colour closest to your work and your contrast colour further away with or without a colourwork ring if this is your first colourwork project the best way to learn is to dive right in and experiment to find the method that feels most comfortable to you just be mindful not to work too tightly as this is a common issue in colourwork knitting and to catch your floats when the float is more than for me 4 stitches but i am a very tight knitter so you may be able to get away with a longer float for a more thorough explanation of this i recommend this blogpost by very pink knits which offers a range of tutorials on stranded colourwork http //verypink com/2011/01/13/learn-to-knit-fair-isle-baby-or-adult-cap/ i also recommend watching this video for help on catching floats https //www youtube com/watch v=5fsbwg4xtlw make 1 left this is a left-leaning increase insert your needle under the strand of yarn between the stitch you have just knit and the next stitch from front to back and place it on your left-hand needle knit it through the back loop so that it is twisted yarn-over increases this pattern only uses yarn-over increases these are very simple to work and blend in seamlessly with the colourwork to form a yarn over simply bring your working yarn in front of your work and wrap it around your 6 right-hand needle to form an extra stitch in the next round you will need to work these yarn over stitches through the back loop to prevent holes this is made clear both in the chart and the pattern german short row to work this technique knit across the row until you are told to turn / use the next stitch to turn your work turn your work around so that you are looking at the wrong side making sure that your working yarn is in front of your work slip the last stitch you knitted from your left-hand needle to your right- hand needle pull the working yarn over the top of your needle tightly so that you can see a little inverted v rather than a normal single stitch bring your working yarn all the way around
